titleStmt.title: An additional ordinanace of the Lords and Commons in Parliament: to enable Sir Thomas Middleton knight, serjeant major generall for the sixe counties of North-Wales, to take subscriptions for the raising of forces, for reducing of the said counties to their due obedience, and prevention of the accesse of Irish forces into those parts. And further to enable the said Sir Thomas to put in execution all former ordinances made this present Parliament. Ordered by the Commons in Parliament, that this ordinance be forthwith printed and published. Hen. Elsynge Cler. Parl, Dom. Com.
titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Parliament.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 11 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 6 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

titleStmt.title: An additional ordinanace of the Lords and Commons in Parliament: to enable Sir Thomas Middleton knight, serjeant major generall for the sixe counties of North-Wales, to take subscriptions for the raising of forces, for reducing of the said counties to their due obedience, and prevention of the accesse of Irish forces into those parts. And further to enable the said Sir Thomas to put in execution all former ordinances made this present Parliament. Ordered by the Commons in Parliament, that this ordinance be forthwith printed and published. Hen. Elsynge Cler. Parl, Dom. Com.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: AN ADDITIONALL ORDINANCE OF The Lords and Commons in PARLIAMENT:

To enable Sir THOMAS MIDDLETON Knight, Serjeant Major Generall for the Å¿ixe Counties of North-Wales, to take Å¿ubÅ¿criptions for the raiÅ¿ing of Forces, for reducing of the Å¿aid Counties to their due obedience, and prevention of the AcceÅ¿Å¿e of IriÅ¿h Forces into thoÅ¿e parts.
And further to enable the Å¿aid Sir Thomas to put in execution all former Ordinances made this preÅ¿ent PARLIAMENT.
ORdered by the Commons in Parliament, that this Ordinance be forth with Printed and PubliÅ¿hed.

closer.signed: Hen. ElÅ¿ynge Cler. Parl, Dom. Com.

div.p: London, Printed for Edward Husbands, Feb. 21. 1644.

div.head: An additionall Ordinance.
div.p: THe Lords and Commons aÅ¿Å¿embled in Parliament, taking into their Å¿erious conÅ¿ideration the preÅ¿ent condition of the Counties of Salop and CheÅ¿hire, and the dammage which may accrue to this Kingdome by the frequent landing of IriÅ¿h forces in the Counties of North-Wales, and joyning themÅ¿elves with Å¿uch Delinquents and PapiÅ¿ts as are now in Armes in thoÅ¿e parts againÅ¿t the Parliament, and his MajeÅ¿ties Soveraigne power and Authority therein reÅ¿iding, which tends to the Å¿ubverÅ¿ion of the Å¿undamentall conÅ¿titution, Government and tranquility of this Realme, the Liberty and Priviledges of the Subjects and the ProteÅ¿tant Religion, within his MajeÅ¿ties Dominions, have thought Å¿it that a timely courÅ¿e may be taken for prevention of the acceÅ¿Å¿e of any IriÅ¿h forces into thoÅ¿e parts for the future, by the Å¿pedy reducing of the Å¿ix Counties of North-Wales to their, due obedience to the Parliament.

For the effecting and compleating of which worke it is neceÅ¿Å¿ary that fiveteene hundred foote and three hundred horÅ¿e, be Å¿peedily raiÅ¿ed and levied with Å¿ufficient Armes, Ammunition, and money to pay them for Å¿ix moneths next enÅ¿uing.

To which end and purpoÅ¿e, the Å¿aid Lords and Commons (being well aÅ¿ured of the fidelity and reÅ¿olution of Sir Thomas Middleton Knight one of the members of the HouÅ¿e of Commons and Sergeant-Major generall of the parliament forces for the Å¿aid Å¿ix Counties of North-Wales) Have Ordained, and be it Ordained by
the Å¿ â¢ ide Lords and Commons, that the Å¿aid Sir Tho. Middleton Å¿hall have, and hereby hath, full power and authority, to take the Å¿ubÅ¿criptions of all Å¿uch perÅ¿ons as will voluntarily lend or contribute any Å¿umme or Å¿ummes of money towards the raiÅ¿ing and maintaining of the Å¿aid forces, buying of Armes and Ammunition, and â¢â¢ r other neceÅ¿Å¿aries for the advancement of the Å¿aid Å¿ â¢ rvice, upon Å¿uch tearmes and conditions as the Å¿everall lenders Å¿hall agree, which Å¿ummes of money Å¿o to be Å¿ubÅ¿cribed or lent as aforeÅ¿aid, the Å¿aid Sir Thomas Middleton and his AÅ¿Å¿ignes are hereby authorized to receive and imploy for the Å¿ervice aforeÅ¿aid, and to give notes or acquittances for the Å¿everall Å¿ummes foreceived; which Å¿aid notes or acquittances Å¿hall be a Å¿ufficient Å¿p â¢ ciallty & evidence for the Å¿everall perÅ¿ons, that Å¿hall lend or contribute any money as aforeÅ¿aid, to demand repayment thereof, with Å¿uch increaÅ¿e as Å¿hall be agreed upon, Å¿o as the Å¿ame Å¿hall not exceed 81. percent. And for the better inabling of the Å¿aid Sir Thomas Middleton to make repayment of Å¿uch moneys as Å¿hall be lent for the purpoÅ¿es aforeÅ¿aid, and to performe Å¿uch conditions and agreements as the Å¿everall Å¿ubÅ¿cribers Å¿hall agree unto, and for the maintenance of the Å¿aid forces and advancement of the Å¿aid Å¿ervice. Be it further ordained by the Å¿aid Lords and Commons, that the Å¿aid Sir Thomas Middleton Å¿hall have and hereby hath, full power and authority to put in execution, within the, Å¿everall Counties of Flint, Denbigh, Mountgomery, Merioneth, Carnarvan, and AngleÅ¿ey, the Å¿everall Ordinances of this preÅ¿ent Parliament hereafter mentioned, that is to Å¿ay, the Ordinances for Å¿equeÅ¿tration of Delinquents and PapiÅ¿ts EÅ¿tates,
the Ordinances for the levying of moneys by way of exciÅ¿e or new impoÅ¿t, the Ordinance for the raiÅ¿ing of money by taxing Å¿uch as have not at all contributo â¢â¢ or not according to their eÅ¿tates, the Ordinance for the weekely AÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿ments, and all other Ordinances made this preÅ¿ent Parliament for advance of mo â¢â¢ y through the whole Kingdome and Dominion of Wales, for the Å¿ervice of the King and Parliament, and for the more Å¿peedy raiÅ¿ing of money for the repayment of Å¿uch Å¿ummes as Å¿hall be raiÅ¿edby Å¿ubÅ¿criptions as aforeÅ¿aid. Be it alÅ¿o ordained by the Å¿aid Lords and Commons, that the Å¿aid Sir Thomas Middleton Å¿hall have and hereby hath, full power and authority to Å¿et, and let, the Lands, Tenements and Hereditaments, of Delinquents, which Å¿hall be Å¿eized and Å¿equeÅ¿tred within the Å¿aid Å¿ix Counties of North-Wales, or any of them from yeare to yeare, or by leaÅ¿e, or leaÅ¿es, untill the Å¿aid moneyes Å¿o Å¿ubÅ¿cribed and payed be Å¿atisfied and diÅ¿charged, and the conditions and agreements with the Å¿everall lenders fully performed; And in caÅ¿e the Å¿aid lenders, Å¿hall not receive full Å¿atisfaction of their principall money to be lent as aforeÅ¿aid wi â¢â¢ the intereÅ¿t thereof out of the Delinquents EÅ¿tates, or otherwiÅ¿e before Å¿aid expreÅ¿Å¿ed, that then the ãâã lenders and every of them Å¿hall have the publ â¢â¢ e faith of the Kingdome for the payment of Å¿uch Å¿ummes of mony as Å¿hall be due unto them, and whereas the Å¿aid Counties of North-Wales are wholy Å¿ubjected to the power and Tyranny of the CommiÅ¿sioners of Array, by reaÅ¿on whereof no CommiÅ¿sioners have been named in any of the Å¿aid Counties, for the putting in

executioÌ of any of the Å¿aid Ordinances of Parliament

Be it alÅ¿o Ordained by the Å¿aid Lords and CoÌmons that the Å¿aid Sir Thomas Middleton Å¿hal have, & hereby hath full power and Authority to name and appoint CommiÅ¿Å¿ioners, TreaÅ¿urers, Receivers, Collectors and Agents within the Å¿aid Counties of North-Wales, for the putting in execution of all and every the Ordinances of Parliament, before mentioned, and of all other Ordinances of Parliament, wherein no CommiÅ¿sioners are named for the Å¿aid Counties, which Å¿aid CoÌmiÅ¿sioners and other perÅ¿ons Å¿o to be named & appointed by the Å¿aid Sir Tho: Middleton, Å¿hal by vertue of this preÅ¿ent Ordinance, have as full power & Authority to put the Å¿aid reÅ¿pective Ordinances in execution, as if they were named by the two HouÅ¿es of Parliament, and their names incerted in the Å¿aid reÅ¿pective Ordinances. And be it alÅ¿o Ordained by the Å¿aid Lords & Commons that the Å¿everall Å¿umms of money which Å¿hall be Å¿ent or advancement of the Å¿aid Å¿ervice, and Å¿uch increaÅ¿e as Å¿hall be due for every reÅ¿pective Å¿umme Å¿o let, according to the true intent and meaning of this Ordinance, Å¿hall be Å¿atisfied and payed out of the firÅ¿t money that Å¿hall be raiÅ¿ed within the Å¿aid Counties of North-Wales by vertue of the forementioned Ordinances, and of this preÅ¿ent Ordinance: And the Å¿aid Sir Tho: Middleton is hereby enabled and authoriÅ¿ed to require & take accompts from time to time of the Å¿aid CommiÅ¿sioners, TreaÅ¿urers and other perÅ¿ons, of their doings and proceedings therein, and to give Å¿uch fitting and reaÅ¿onable allowance unto Å¿uch perÅ¿ons as Å¿hall bee employed in the execution of the Ordinances aforeÅ¿aid, and of this preÅ¿ent Ordinance, or any of them, for their pains and charges
therein, as the Å¿aid Sir Tho: Middleton Å¿hall thinke Å¿it, provided, that Å¿uch allowance Å¿hall not exceed the reÅ¿pective rates allowed in the City of London and other parts of the Kingdome; for the putting of the Å¿aid Ordinances in execution. And be it further Ordained that the rents and profits of the Waterworke brought to London by Sir Hugh Middleton Baronet deceaÅ¿ed, belonging to his MajeÅ¿ty, or to any delinquent, Å¿hall from time to time be paid unto the Å¿aid Sir Tho: Middleton to bee employed in the Å¿aid Å¿ervice, and that Delinquents perÅ¿onall eÅ¿tates within the Cities of London and WeÅ¿tminÅ¿ter; and the Suburbs thereof, not yet Å¿equeÅ¿tred nor diÅ¿covered, and which Å¿hall be diÅ¿covered by the Å¿aid Sir Tho: Middleton, within one moneth next after the publiÅ¿hing of this Ordinance in print, Å¿hall be allowed unto the Å¿aid Sir Tho: Middleton for the advancement of the Å¿aid Å¿ervice, provided alwayes that the Å¿aid concealed EÅ¿tates doe not exceed the Å¿umme of 3000 pounds: And that the Å¿aid Sir Tho: Middleton doe not poÅ¿Å¿eÅ¿Å¿e himÅ¿elfe thereof before hee acquaint the Committee of Lords and Commons for SequeÅ¿trations therewith, to the end they may judge of the delinquencie of the perÅ¿on before his eÅ¿tate be Å¿equenÅ¿tred and taken away.

And the Å¿aid Sir Tho: Middleton is hereby authoriÅ¿ed to adminiÅ¿ter the Å¿everall Oathes Å¿pecified in the foreÅ¿aid Ordinances unto Å¿uch CommiÅ¿sioners and perÅ¿ons, as by the true meaning of the Å¿aid ordinances, of theÅ¿e preÅ¿ents or any of them) ought to take the Å¿ame. And be it further Ordained, That whatÅ¿oever the Å¿aid Sir Tho: Middleton, or any other perÅ¿on Å¿hall doe or
cauÅ¿e to be done in perÅ¿uance to this or any other the Å¿aid Ordinances of Parliament, within the Å¿aid Counties of North-Wales; the Å¿ame is ratified & confirmed by the power and authority of Parliament: And that the Å¿aid Sir Tho: Middleton Å¿hall render an accompt of all his doings and proceedings in the Å¿aid Å¿ervice, to the two HouÅ¿es of Parliament: And that he, the Å¿aid Sir Tho: Middleton and all other perÅ¿ons whatÅ¿oever, imployed in the execution of the Å¿aid Ordinances; or any of them, Å¿hal be Å¿aved and kept harmeleÅ¿Å¿e in their perÅ¿ons and EÅ¿tates, for their doings and proceedings in the premiÅ¿es by the power and authority of Parliament.
ORdered by the Commons AÅ¿Å¿embled in Parliament that this Ordinance be forthwith Printed and PubliÅ¿hed.

closer.signed: Hen. ElÅ¿ynge. Cler. Parl. Dom. Com.
